docs.lead_paragraph: Organized labor reasserted some of its old political clout last month when it helped persuade Congressional Democrats to defeat urgently needed free-trade legislation. The unions had contributed huge sums to the Democrats, and when an issue came along that seemed to threaten jobs and wages, they called in their chits. But in the cynical competition for Congressional votes, another familiar player -- private industry -- was absent. Businesses that would normally have promised big money to persuade Democrats to vote the other way were nowhere to be found. The reason, according to a new study, is that business is deserting the Democrats. When the trade vote took place, Democrats noted and in many cases openly rejoiced in labor's resurgence. At the same time, they privately wondered about the disappearance of business groups in high technology, financial services and other areas that would predictably have pressed them to support legislation giving the President enhanced power to negotiate trade agreements. A new study by the Center for Responsive Politics, an independent group, suggests an answer.
docs.abstract: Editorial says absence of business lobby from Congressional battle over bill to give Pres Clinton fast-track trade authority, which was defeated with help from organized labor, suggests that business may be deserting Democrats and that phenomenon may have tremendous political implications for legislative battles to come; comments on finding by Center for Responsive Politics that every broad category of business now supports Republicans (M)
docs.snippet: Organized labor reasserted some of its old political clout last month when it helped persuade Congressional Democrats to defeat urgently needed free-trade legislation. The unions had contributed huge sums to the Democrats, and when an issue came...

docs.lead_paragraph: Late on a November afternoon two years ago, a 36-year-old Scientologist named Lisa McPherson was involved in a minor traffic accident. She was not injured, but she inexplicably stripped off her clothes and began to walk naked down the street. A paramedic rushed her into an ambulance and asked why she had taken off her clothes. Ms. McPherson replied: ''I wanted help. I wanted help.'' She was taken to a nearby hospital for a psychiatric examination, but several Scientologists arrived and explained that their religion opposes psychiatry. Ms. McPherson asked to leave and, against medical advice, she was released into the care of the Scientologists.

headline.main: DISTRUST IN CLEARWATER -- A special report.; Death of a Scientologist Heightens Suspicions in a Florida Town

docs.abstract: Death of Lisa McPherson, 36-year-old Church of Scientology member at church facility in Clearwater, Fla, rekindles deep suspicions within retirement community, where residents have never completely overcome fear and distrust generated by organization's clandestine arrival there more than 20 years ago, special report, Distrust in Clearwater; McPherson died 17 days after her release into care of Scientologists, against medical advice, after she was found naked on street after involvement in minor traffic accident; circumstances surrounding her death have raised questions over whether it was caused by church's handling of her medical treatment, particularly its failure for philospohical reasons to provide psychiatric care; county medical examiner says McPherson was deprived of water for at least her last five to 10 days and died of blood clot brought on by severe dehydration; church officials deny responsibility; say death was accidental and accuse police of waging vendetta; incident has offered penetrating look into Scientology's relationship with its members, whose lives it completely controls; sheds light on financial demands placed by church on its members to increase contributions since it received long-sought tax-exempt status from Internal Revenue Service in 1991; critics worldwide say organizxation is nothing other than cult and money machine intended mainly to bilk faithful, who must pay large sums to undergo counseling sessions; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Who are we? What are we doing here? When the Federal Government wants answers to existential questions, it turns to the Census Bureau. Internet explorers have existential questions, too. They can also turn to the Census Bureau. How many Americans are 100 years or older? (58,000.) What percentage of workers car pool? (13.4 percent.) Which state had the highest average annual pay last year? (New York, at $36,831.) Which American Indian tribe is the largest? (Cherokees, with a population of 369,035.) How many people regularly play golf? (24 million.)

headline.main: Taking In the Sites; Census Bureau Tells Something About Everything

docs.abstract: Taking in the Sites column discusses what is available on Census Bureau and other web sites that provide demographic information (M)
